Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Organizational Responsiveness to Open Outside Input: A Modeling Approach based on Statistical Text and Network Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on the development of new analytical tools for modeling the relationships between intra-organizational communication networks and open, external sources of text data. The massive quantities of textual communications generated within organizations constitute a largely untapped source for insightful, timely organizational analytics. The tools under development for this project are designed to jointly analyze the content of communications and the socio-organizational structure comprised by communication ties, thereby allowing researchers and practitioners to identify and analyze the ways in which government officials' extra-governmental communications are related to intra-governmental communications and operations. In producing these tools, this project builds upon extant textual and network analysis methods by focusing on novel probabilistic methods for identifying topics that cut across network domains (e.g., informal email communications, official meeting minutes, and final policy records) and representing the complex flow of topics through government decision and policy-making processes. These methods, along with data collected during the course of this project, enhance organizations' ability to connect streams of external input to their internal operations. In conjunction with a new, publicly available database of local government communication records, this project showcases and builds upon the success of recent efforts, encompassing the gov2.0 movement, to improve government responsiveness through the solicitation of open outside input.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project entailed three major aims. First, we sought to gather data that shed light on patterns of communication inside local governments in the United States. Specifically, we gathered communication data that came in the form of interpersonal messages that included the message text---email. Second, we sought to develop and disseminate tools for using statistical methods for analyzing data comprised by interpersonal textual messages. Third, we sought to use the methods we have developed to study patterns of internal government communication.
In terms of data collection, we gathered a corpus of email communications from North Carolina county governments. The dataset includes over 500,000 messages, covers more than twenty counties, and spans 1--3 months within each county. As we gathered this data, we ran an experiment in which we let some counties know about other counties that had fulfilled our request in the past. We found that a county was significantly more likely to fulfill our request if it was told that a neighboring county had previously fulfilled the same request.
In terms of methods development, we have developed two new statistical methods. One of the methods simultaneously identifies the major topics of discussion reflected in the text, and the patterns of who talks to whom about each topic. The second method we developed is focused on analyzing patterns in how who talks to whom changes over time, and can be used to predict future patterns of communication. We have developed open source software that can be used by researchers who want to apply the methods we have developed.
The in-depth analysis of the patterns of communication reflected in the email data is the most preliminary component of our work on this project, as we needed to gather the data and develop our methods before we could turn to data analysis. Our first study using the data and methods for this project is focused on the role of gender in shaping patterns of internal county government communication. Our analysis to date suggests three general findings. First, women are generally excluded from conversation at a higher rate than are men. Second, women are particularly underrepresented in topics of conversation related to what we term the 'locus of control' in the county government---topics covering the budget and major policy decisions. The third finding is that, as the proportion county department managers are women increases, the likelihood that each woman is excluded from communications as a whole, and the locus of control in particular, decreases.
